Sending Messages

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe and configure the plugin used to
send messages

¢ Describe the functionality of safe ordering

¢ Describe how a sending message error is
handled

Use case

¢ The bank account verification
payload must be sent to an external
system

* Configure the system to handle
send errors

* Configure the system to ensure a
contact message is not sent until its
previous message is acknowledged

Gi

a Fe N

class

Configure the plugin
Configure the destination

* The message transport plugin is responsible for sending the message
* The message transport plugin may also become responsible for:
+ Persisting the SenderReflD in a message if the SenderReflD is provided by an external system

+ Acknowledging in case of synchronous message exchange with an external system

| Create a message transport plugin class

¢ Use a package naming convention recommendation:

* <company>.<app_code>.messaging.<functional_area>

© BankAccountVerfcaton Transport.gs

| resume and suspend methods example Gi

a override function resume() {

—> _bankApi = new BankVerificationAPI()
_bankapi .config.Http.Authentication.Basic.Username = "externalappuser”
_bankApi .Config.Http.Authentication.Basic.Password = "gw"

}

¢ To resume a destination, call the resume method
* resume method establishes and configures the connection
* To suspend a destination, call the suspend method

* suspend method releases any resources

| Send payload to web service example Gi

@Param("aMessage", "Message object")
@Param("transformedPayload", "Payload sent by request plugin")
@ override function send(aMessage : Message, transformedPayload : String) {
var acclumber = (aMessage.MessageRoot as BankAccount) .AccountNumber
—> var ackCode = bankApi.verifyAccount (aMessage.SenderRefID, transformedPayload, accNumber)

* To send a message, implement the send method, which the application calls with
a Message entity instance argument

* The send method has two arguments:
* aMessage is the original payload

¢ transformedPayload is the transformed payload if that destination implemented
a MessageRequest plugin

| Send payload to file example Gi

ot override function send(aMessage: Message, transformedPayload: String) {
print("\n*#* Stage 3(b) -- Sending the message *#*")
print(" Transport plugin: VendorRecommendationTransport -- send()")

print(" Sending payload to file c:/Guidewire/Vendor" + aMessage.ABContact.PublicID + ".txt")
var file = "c:/Guidewire/Vendor" + aMessage.ABContact.PublicID + ".txt"

var output = new Bufferediriter (new FileWriter(new File(file)))

output. write (transformedPayload)

4 output.close()

AE

« VendorRecommendationTransport plugin
* The send method uses Gosu's Java file I/O capabilities to write the payload to a simple flat file

¢ The payload contains information about the evaluations for that vendor

« Some destinations create multiple messages for a single entity or a single set of
related entities

* Typically, they should not be sent at the same time
« Later messages reference work done in earlier messages

¢ If an earlier message gets lost or arrives late, a later message will not make sense

| Safe ordering

* Guidewire has a built-in mechanism called safe ordering

+ Its primary purpose is to ensure that the external system gets related messages one at a time
« When safe ordering is enforced:

+ For a given destination/entity pair, only one message is sent

+ The external system must acknowledge the first message before the next message is sent

| Default ordering and sending behavior Gi

| Transport or Request plugin error

Se -: —

¢ When Transport or Request plugins throws an exception, the Guidewire
application automatically:

* Compares message send attempts to Max Retries

« Waits the Initial Retry Interval

* Retries to send message

* Increases the time between resends (Retry Backoff Multiplier)
* Continues until reaching Max Retries

* Parameters defined in message destination

| Error administration

om
Ges

¢ Guidewire automatically suspends a destination when exceeding Max Retries
* No further messages are sent for destination

¢ An administrator must manually resume the destination

* The message that caused the suspend will be resent, up to the maximum retries if necessary

Question

_— — Every destination can optionally have a request plugin, but it must have a
¢ transport plugin. Why is the transport plugin required?

¢
¢

Seo e Soo e esses see sen

Gi

Answer Gi

_— — Every destination can optionally have a request plugin, but it must have a
Y transport plugin. Why is the transport plugin required?
¢

The transport plugin is required because it is used to send the message when it is
processed from the Message table. Without a transport plugin, messages for a given
destination would have no way of being sent to the corresponding external system.

Soo ee See eo eS se ese

Question

,- — Can one destination have two transport plugins? Can one transport
¢ plugin be used by two destinations?

¢
¢

Seo e Soo e esses see sen

Gi

Answer Gi

,~ — Can one destination have two transport plugins? Can one transport
Y plugin be used by two destinations?
¢

A destination can’t have two transport plugins, but a transport plugin class can be used
by two (or more) similar destinations.

Soo ee See eo eS se ese

Question

_- — Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external

Y systems?
¢

Seo e Soo e esses see sen

Gi

Answer Gi

_- — Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external
Y systems?
¢

The message acknowledgement architecture assumes that each message is sent to
only one destination. If a given send method sent a message to multiple destinations,
then there could be multiple acknowledgements, errors, or unprocessed messages,
and the messaging architecture would not be able to identify the state of the message.

Soo ee See eo eS se ese

review send messages

¢ Describe the functionality of safe ordering
¢ Describe how a sending message error is
handled

A destination can’t have two transport plugins, but a transport plugin class can be used
by two (or more) similar destinations.

Question

_- — Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external

Y systems?
¢

Seo e Soo e esses see sen

Gi

Answer Gi

_- — Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external
Y systems?
¢

The message acknowledgement architecture assumes that each message is sent to
only one destination. If a given send method sent a message to multiple destinations,
then there could be multiple acknowledgements, errors, or unprocessed messages,
and the messaging architecture would not be able to identify the state of the message.
